description: From Middle English silver, selver, sulver, from Old English seolfor, seolofor (“silver”), from Proto-West Germanic *silubr, from Proto-Germanic *silubrą (“silver”), of uncertain origin.
Adjective sense of twenty-fifth wedding anniversary generalized from silver wedding, from German Silberhochzeit, silberne Hochzeit.

adjectives.description: From Middle English silver, selver, sulver, from Old English seolfor, seolofor (“silver”), from Proto-West Germanic *silubr, from Proto-Germanic *silubrą (“silver”), of uncertain origin. Adjective sense of twenty-fifth wedding anniversary generalized from silver wedding, from German Silberhochzeit, silberne Hochzeit.
silver (comparative more silver, superlative most silver)

entries.meaning: Having a color like silver: a shiny gray.
Denoting the twenty-fifth anniversary, especially of a wedding.
examples: Mostly, these have been relationships of 10 or less years. However, one respondent has celebrated her silver wedding anniversary.

entries.meaning: (of commercial services) Premium, but inferior to gold.
Having the clear, musical tone of silver; soft and clear in sound.
(uncountable) A lustrous, white, metallic element, atomic number 47, atomic weight 107.87, symbol Ag.
(collectively) Coins made from silver or any similar white metal.
examples: […]  maybe two or three twenties, a dozen tens, and twenty or thirty fins. The rest is all aces and silver.

entries.meaning: (collectively) Cutlery and other eating utensils, whether silver or made from some other white metal.
(collectively) Any items made from silver or any other white metal.
Anything resembling silver; something shiny and white.

verbs.description: silver (third-person singular simple present silvers, present participle silvering, simple past and past participle silvered)

entries.meaning: To cover with silver, or with a silvery metal.
examples: to silver a pin;  to silver a glass mirror plate with an amalgam of tin and mercury

entries.meaning: To polish like silver; to impart a brightness to, like that of silver.
To make hoary, or white, like silver.
